item.title: Intel is Now Pricier Than TSMC: That Makes No Sense
item.description:
Intel is Now Pricier Than TSMC: That Makes No Sense
Intelâ€™s stock price has more than doubled in the past five months, since President Donald Trump announced the U.S. government would buy a 10% stake in the ailing chip manufacturer, followed by similar investments from SoftBank and Nvidia. Investors are betting the new capital, coupled with a surge in AI demand, will help resuscitate the company. Those expectations will collide with reality when Intel reports fourth-quarter earnings late this afternoon, either making or breaking the rally. Intel bears say the stock has moved way too high, setting it up for a big sell-off on Friday morningâ€”particularly if the companyâ€™s outlook for 2026 disappoints.
Jan 22, 2026

True Value

Intel is Now Pricier Than TSMC: That Makes No Sense

By Anita Ramaswamy

Intelâ€™s stock price has more than doubled in the past five months, since President Donald Trump announced the U.S. government would buy a 10% stake in the ailing chip manufacturer, followed by similar investments from SoftBank and Nvidia. Investors are betting the new capital, coupled with a surge in AI demand, will help resuscitate the company.

Those expectations will collide with reality when Intel reports fourth-quarter earnings late this afternoon, either making or breaking the rally. Intel bears say the stock has moved way too high, setting it up for a big sell-off on Friday morning—particularly if the companyâ€™s outlook for 2026 disappoints.

Read the full article

The Takeaway

  • Intel’s stock valuation now exceeds TSMC’s
  • Intel’s revenue has declined, missing the AI chip boom that boosted TSMC.
  • Analysts question Intel’s high valuation given execution risks and PC reliance.

The AI Break, Rui Sousa, and Luis Sousa

Hey fam 👋 Luis & Rui here with your Thursday AI coffee break.

This week, Apple’s Siri could be turning into a real chatbot, Claude’s “new constitution” just dropped, and YouTube is about to let creators generate Shorts using their own AI likeness.

Grab your coffee!
(3-minute coffee break☕)

AI News around the world 🌎

🍏 Apple is turning Siri into an AI bot that’s more like ChatGPT, as Apple races to modernize Siri with more advanced AI. (continue reading)

📜 Anthropic released a new “constitution” describing Claude’s intended values and behavior and made it freely reusable under CC0. (continue reading)

🎬 YouTube says creators will soon be able to generate Shorts using their own AI likeness, alongside other new AI creation tools and controls. (continue reading)

🎓 OpenAI launches “Education for Countries” to help governments and universities scale AI in education, including access to ChatGPT Edu and training/certifications. (continue reading)

🚨 Tutorial: Build Your Own AI Employees with Claude Skills

Tired of copy-pasting the same prompts into Claude every single day?

This 15-minute guide shows you how to set up Claude Skills that remember exactly how you want work done.

Inside: Tutorial + 5 ready-to-paste Skills (LinkedIn posts, status reports, meeting notes, cold emails, landing page copy).

👉 Read the Claude Skills Tutorial here

Trending AI Tools 🛠

✍️ HoppyCopy: AI copywriter built for email marketing: generate newsletters, sequences, subject lines, and ad copy fast.

🧱 10Web: AI website builder for WordPress: generate a site from a prompt, then edit + optimize speed and performance.

💬 Stirling: Create ads at scale by using your page url.

🤖 MaybeTech: AI Agents that operate inside Slack or Teams, connect to the tools you already use, and take ownership of clearly defined workflows. (great for ops).

  • 💰 UpScale AI: Raised $200M (Tiger Global) to build AI networking (link)

  • 🚀 Breez AI: Raised $1.3M pre-seed (Wamda Capital-backed) (link)

Prompt of the Week 🧠

Customer Support → Turn messy tickets into clear SOPs.

If you manage support (or ops), this prompt helps you turn real customer issues into repeatable processes your team can follow.

Prompt:

You are an Operations Lead building internal SOPs from customer support tickets.

Your job: transform the ticket thread below into a clear, repeatable SOP that any new team member can follow.

Output format (exact):
- SOP Title (max 8 words)
- When to use this SOP (1 sentence)
- Goal (1 sentence)
- Required info to collect (bullet list)
- Step-by-step process (numbered steps)
- Decision tree (If/Then bullets for the 3 most common branches)
- Copy-paste responses (3 templates: “first reply”, “need more info”, “resolved”)
- Escalation rules (when to escalate + to who)
- SOP owner + review cadence (suggest a role + how often to review)

Constraints:
- Keep it practical, short sentences, no fluff
- Assume the reader is new to the company
- Highlight any missing info as “⚠️ Missing”

Ticket thread (paste everything):
[PASTE TICKET / EMAIL THREAD HERE]

Company context (optional):
- Product: [what you sell]
- Tools: [Zendesk/Intercom/Slack/etc.
- Refund policy: [paste if relevant]

Where to use it:
Support teams, ops teams, founders handling support themselves, onboarding new reps, building a knowledge base fast.

Source Code

What the Team Behind Cursor Knows About the Future of Code

Cursor team members share their thoughts on building software with AI and why model selection beats prompting tricks

by Katie Parrott

Happening now: Weâ€™re hosting Vibe Code Camp with the worldâ€™s best experts pushing the limits of whatâ€™s possible. Watch live now until 6 p.m. ET, and catch the recordings. Also: This article is based on a sponsored event. Cursor provided $100 in credits to attendees and made this camp possible.â€”Kate Lee

A few minutes into Everyâ€™s first Cursor Camp, Cursor developer education lead Lee Robinson made a bold declaration: â€œThe IDE is kind of dead.â€

IIDE stands for â€œintegrated development environmentâ€â€”basically Microsoft Word, but for code. Itâ€™s where programmers type, organize files, and run programs, and for decades, it has been the center of a programmerâ€™s world.

Now, that model is breaking down. The center of gravity has shifted from typing code by hand in an IDE such as Visual Studio Code to managing AI agents that write it for you with a tool such as Cursor.

In this session, Lee and Samantha Whitmore, a software engineer at Cursor, walked us through how they work in a post-IDE world. What follows are the workflows, model-selection strategies, and honest limitations they sharedâ€”plus where this leaves you if youâ€™re trying to figure out what the future of code looks like.

Key takeaways

  1. The agent is becoming the core. Writing and editing code by hand is shrinking as a percentage of the work. Developers are now spending more time telling AI agents what to build and reviewing their output.
  2. Cloud and local agents are merging. Youâ€™ll soon be able to start an agent on your computer, hand it off to remote servers when you close your laptop, and pick it back up laterâ€”no context lost.
  3. Model choice matters more than prompting tricks. Prompting gimmicks like, â€œIâ€™ll pay you $1,000,â€ which some AI users swore could make AI provide a better output, donâ€™t work anymore. You need to choose the right model for the jobâ€”say, one for brainstorming, another for deep bug-hunting.
  4. Agents can run for weeks. Cursorâ€™s research team built a working web browser from scratch using AI agents that ran for days, producing 3 million lines of code. It cost $80,000 in tokens (the units AI companies use to measure and charge for usage). Itâ€™s a research project thatâ€™s not available for public useâ€”for now. But it shows where things are heading.

Move fast, donâ€™t break things

Most AI coding tools donâ€™t know which line of code will actually break your system. Try Augment Code, which understands your entire codebase, including the repos, languages, and dependencies that actually runs your business, and use their playbook to learn more about their framework, checklists, and assessments. Ship 30% faster with 40% shorter merge times.

Playbook at augmentcode.com
Want to sponsor Every? Click here.

What â€˜the death of the IDEâ€™ means

Cursor looks like a traditional coding tool on the surface. There are files on the left, code in the middle, and now an AI chat panel on the side, where you can ask the agent to do things.


For many Cursor users, that chat panel has become the main event. Some donâ€™t even look at the code output muchâ€”they work entirely in conversation with the AI, only reviewing the final result.

According to Lee, developers used to interact with Cursor primarily by writing code by hand and using an autocomplete function, where the AI suggests the next line of code as you type, similar to predictive text on your phone. But Lee says recent Cursorâ€™s usage data tells a different story: More and more developers are working inside the agent interface. He said that writing code by hand may comprise as little as 10 percent of the time for some developers.

This is why he believes that easier text editingâ€”for which Cursor and tools like it were originally builtâ€”is less important than the coding agentâ€”which writes and edits codeâ€”and the ability to review the agentâ€™s output and track changes.

And with new tools and integrations being built every day (like Everyâ€™s compound engineering plugin), it seems likely the old ways of AI-enabled coding will slip farther down the ranking.

A browser built from scratch by AI (for $80,000)

When you use an AI coding tool, youâ€™re really using two things: the model (the AI brain that generates code) and the scaffolding known as the harness around it (the infrastructure that lets that brain do thingsâ€”run commands, edit files, handle errors, and manage context). The model comes from OpenAI or Anthropic. The harness is what Cursor builds.

The same model can perform very differently depending on its harness. A well-tuned harness knows how to feed the model the right context, when to truncate long outputs, how to recover from errors, and how to keep the AI on track during long tasks.

To stress-test what a well-tuned harness could do, Cursorâ€™s team built a custom research harness around GPT 5.2 and set it loose on an absurd task: building a fully functional web browser from scratch. AI produced 3 million lines of code across thousands of files, generated over weeks of continuous running, at a cost of around $80,000 in tokens. The browser that resulted could render web pages, handle Flexbox (a layout system for web design), display images, and run scripts.

At $80,000, this is a hefty research project, not something your average solo developer could try on a Tuesday afternoon. But a year ago, the same task would have been impossible at any price. If costs continue to come down, â€œLet the agent run for a week on something ambitiousâ€ might feel less like a stunt in time.

How a Cursor coder uses Cursor

Cursorâ€™s team uses Cursor to build Cursor. Their workflows are both a window into power-user techniques and a preview of where the tool is headed because the features they find themselves wanting tend to become the features they build.

Sam showed how sheâ€™s building features for Cursorâ€™s cloud agents product, including the ability to move an agent from your local computer to the cloudâ€”in other words, a remote serverâ€”and back.

Right now, if you start an AI agent on your laptop and then close it for lunch, the agent stops. Samâ€™s project would let you hand the agent off to run in the cloud, check on its progress from your phone, and have it back your computer when youâ€™re ready.

Planning comes first

Before Sam writes any code, she spends serious time in â€œplan mode,â€ a Cursor feature where you talk to the AI about what you want to build before it starts building. For complex projects, sheâ€™ll share designs and screenshots, and have a long conversation to create a detailed plan.

The more detailed your upfront plan, the less the AI wanders off into expensive tangents. â€œPlan modeâ€œâ€”whether in Cursor, Claude Code, or any other toolâ€”has become gospel among top AI-powered coders.

For large plans, Sam uses multiple agents working in parallel, manually breaking the work into pieces. For small-to-medium plans, she might use one or two agents. For simple bug fixes, she sometimes skips planning entirely.

Model selection is based on vibes

Sam has developed what she calls â€œpersonal vibe assessmentsâ€ for different AI models, rough heuristics for when to use which model:

  1. Claude Opus: This is Samâ€™s brainstorming buddy. Itâ€™s good at connecting dots and helping when something is poorly specified, plus it can zoom out and correct itself.
  2. GPT 5.2 Codex High: Sam says Codex has â€œrobotic energy.â€ It takes you at your exact word. Itâ€™s also incredibly thorough for bug-finding, but it can get fixated on one approach instead of stepping back to try something different.

Sometimes she uses both at once, running the same task through multiple models in parallel and comparing the results. Cursor has a feature called â€œbest of nâ€ that lets you run up to eight models simultaneously on the same problem. Sometimes, if a bug is tricky to fix, Sam will have Codex and Opus go head-to-head to see which modelâ€™s approach comes out on top.

When multiple models return different answers, she interviews them. Sheâ€™ll ask one model to justify its approach, then share that reasoning with another model and ask what it thinks. Itâ€™s a bit manual, but it helps her understand the problem deeply before deciding what to do.

Review is part of the workflow

Cursor has built-in review tools. Thereâ€™s a â€œfind issuesâ€ button that kicks off another agent to review the code from a fresh perspective. They also have a tool called Bugbot that automatically reviews GitHub pull requests (the drafts developers submit before code goes live) and flags likely bugs.

Sam said Cursor has an internal policy: Donâ€™t merge code until youâ€™ve addressed all Bugbot comments.

Retrieval over compression

Sam has shifted her thinking in one more way recently. She used to think you needed to compress conversations into summaries for AI to remember past work. Now she prefers a â€œretrieval firstâ€ approach: Instead of summaries, she gives the AI pointers to past conversations and plan documents and lets it explore them as needed.

â€œThe agents have gotten so good at exploring pointers to files,â€ she said.

Q&A highlights

Q: Where is the early access channel for new features?

In Cursor settings under â€œbeta,â€ you can choose between stable, early access, and nightly releases. Lee recommended early access for people who want to try new features without dealing with frequent bugs or crashes.

Q: How does Cursor handle context as agents run longer?

Cursor now uses a â€œpointerâ€ system. Instead of stuffing the AIâ€™s memory with full documents, it gives the agent pointers to files and lets it explore them as needed. This prevents the AI from getting confused by too much information at once.

â€œThe models are smart enough now to go explore it and use file read tools and grep tools to explore this context as it needs,â€ Sam said. Grep refers to a command to search for and find matching text patterns in files.

Q: Do prompting tricks like â€œIâ€™ll pay you $1,000â€ still work?

No. The Cursor team said steering the model with rewards or threats has become less important than managing context pollution (preventing the AI from being overwhelmed with irrelevant information). The models are already well-trained for coding tasksâ€”the trick is staying out of their way.

Q: I do simple websites from Figma designs. I canâ€™t get agents to match the design faster than doing it myself.

Sam said this is tricky for companies like Cursor. The Figma integration is built by Figma, not the AI companies, so the models havenâ€™t been trained on how to use it. Youâ€™ll likely need to experiment more with your prompts to get good results.

For straightforward design-to-code translationâ€”taking a static design and turning it into working code, the bread and butter of many web developersâ€”AI tools still donâ€™t reliably beat human speed. The gains seem concentrated in more complex, multi-step tasks where the AI can run longer and handle more scope.

Questions to ask before switching

As someone without a software engineering background but who vibe codes frequently, hereâ€™s what I came away from this camp thinking: Cursorâ€™s vision is compellingâ€”agents that run for weeks, seamlessly move between your laptop and the cloud, and handle projects that would take human developers months. But the gap between the demo and daily reality is worth examining.

A few things stood out:

The cost barrier is realâ€”for now. Sam admitted she â€œliterally never looks atâ€ token usage, relying on the $200-per-month unlimited plan. For people doing simpler tasks or with smaller budgets, the calculus might be different.

Design translation remains hard. The question about Figma-to-code workflows didnâ€™t get a satisfying answer. If youâ€™re a web developer doing straightforward implementation work, these tools may not save you time yet.

Model selection is becoming its own expertise. Knowing when to use Opus versus Codex, run multiple models in parallel, and interview the AI about its choices, among other things, is emerging as its own skill set.

That shift has implications beyond professional developers. If agents can build browsers from scratch, what else becomes possible for people whoâ€™ve never written a line of code?

The answer, based on what I saw: complex, multi-step projects where you can describe what you want and review what you get. The simpler the taskâ€”the more itâ€™s about matching a specific design or writing a single functionâ€”the less these tools help.

Whether the IDE is â€œdeadâ€ or evolving, one thing is clear: The teams building these tools have huge amounts of influence on the direction AI-powered coding is headed. Itâ€™s good to know what theyâ€™re buildingâ€”and to test their claims against your own experience.

  • â€¢ The pin, expected to launch by 2027 with 20 million units, aims to compete with OpenAIâ€™s anticipated AI hardware, potentially a pair of earbuds, signaling growing competition in the AI hardware market.

Article Summary:

  • â€¢ While the fake citations represent a small fraction of the total, their presence raises concerns about the integrity of scholarly publishing and the challenges of peer review under the pressure of massive submission volumes.
  • â€¢ The findings underscore a broader issue: if leading AI researchers struggle to verify AI-generated outputs, it raises questions about the reliability of AI usage in other fields.

item.title: ðŸ«³ðŸ¼ A crawling, detachable robot hand
item.description:
PLUS: Zipline comes to more cities  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

January 22nd, 2026   |   Read Online

Read Online | Sign Up | Advertise

Good morning, TT. EPFL roboticists just built a robotic hand that can detach itself and crawl away from its arm â€” basically â€œThingâ€ from The Addams Family, but engineered in Switzerland.

With freakishly flexible, reversible fingers, it can grip from either side â€” and even juggle extra tasks with a sixth digit. Is this the next big leap in real-world dexterity?

 

In todayâ€™s robotics rundown:

  • Robotic hand detaches and crawls on its own

  • Zipline soars to $7.6B as it targets Houston, Phoenix

  • Sailbots take on Category 5 hurricanes

  • Serve Robotics moves into hospital bots

  • Quick hits on other robotics news

LATEST DEVELOPMENTS

EPFL

âœŒðŸ¼ Robotic hand detaches and crawls on its own

Image source: EPFL

The Rundown: Researchers at Switzerlandâ€™s EPFL just built a robotic hand that can detach from its arm, scuttle across a surface, and grab objects beyond the reach of conventional manipulators.

The details:

  • The EPFL team built this robotic hand from 3D printable parts, with the ability to detach from its arm, crawl, grab objects, and reattach itself.

  • The reversible design lets any finger combination form opposing thumb-like pairs, enabling grasping from either side without repositioning.

  • Each finger bends in both directions with more than twice the range of motion of a human hand, optimized via genetic algorithms for grasping and locomotion.

  • With five fingers, it replicates most human grasps; add a sixth finger, and it can tackle two-handed tasks singlehandedly, like unscrewing a large bottle cap.

Why it matters: This hand challenges a core assumption in robotics â€” that manipulators must stay bolted to their arms. By treating it as an autonomous agent that can deploy, complete a task, and return, EPFLâ€™s design hints at a future where robotic limbs become interchangeable tools rather than fixed appendages.

ZIPLINE

ðŸŒ¯Â Zipline soars to $7.6B as it targets Houston, Phoenix

Image source: Zipline

The Rundown: Zipline just raised more than $600M to fuel a fresh U.S. push that will launch its autonomous drone delivery in Houston and Phoenix in early 2026 and support expansion into at least four states.

The details:

  • Ziplineâ€™s valuation has nearly tripled in under three years, leaping from $2.75B in mid-2021 to $7.6B today.

  • Zipline says it has surpassed 2M commercial deliveries globally, with its drones flying more than 125M autonomous miles and delivering over 20M items.

  • The company began operations in 2016, delivering blood by drone in Rwanda, and has spent the past decade building a vertically integrated logistics stack.

  • Its Platform 2 drones, tailored for suburban home delivery, can carry up to 8 lb. within a 10â€‘mile radius, while the Platform 1 handles 120â€‘mile round trips.

Why it matters: Zipline says its newest U.S. sites can ramp to 100 deliveries a day in just two days, turning what used to be slow, geofenced pilots into something that starts to look like real infrastructure. Rivals Amazon Prime Air and Walmartâ€™s drone partners Wing and DroneUp are pushing hard too â€” the drone wars are officially on.

CLIMATE ROBOTICS

ðŸŒŠÂ Sailbots take on Category 5 hurricanes

Image source: Oshen

The Rundown: Bootstrapped UK startup Oshen has built swarms of low-cost autonomous â€œC-Starâ€ robots that recently became the first ocean bots to survive and collect data from inside a Category 5 hurricane, its founder told Techcrunch.

The details:

  • Oshen builds autonomous micro-robots that can survive up to 100 days at sea and are cheap enough to deploy in swarms for ocean data collection.

  • Founder Anahita Laverack launched the company in 2022 after realizing how little real-time ocean data exists for weather and climate modeling.

  • OAA commissioned Oshen to deploy C-Stars near the U.S. Virgin Islands for Hurricane Humberto; three of five bots rode out the full Category 5 storm.

  • Oshen, now based in Plymouth (Englandâ€™s marine tech hub), is signing new government and defense contracts, including with the UK government.

Why it matters: Oshenâ€™s C-Star swarms show how micro-robots could plug a critical gap in hurricane and climate models by streaming real-time data from places that are tough to reach, intensifying competition with larger uncrewed fleets like Saildroneâ€™s USVs already collecting high-res storm data for NOAA and navies worldwide.

SERVE ROBOTICS

ðŸ¥Â Serve Robotics moves into hospital bots

Image source: Serve Robotics

The Rundown: Serve Robotics is pushing beyond burrito runs into the far messier world of hospital logistics, agreeing to buy Austin-based Diligent Robotics in an all-stock deal valuing the startup at about $29M.

The details:

  • The deal extends Serve from sidewalk delivery to hospital logistics, but CEO Ali Kashani frames it as a natural expansion of the same autonomy stack.

  • Diligentâ€™s Moxi robots are already one of the largest deployed hospital service fleets in the U.S., with roughly 100 robots across more than 25 hospitals.

  • Serve plans to keep Diligent operating independently while sharing software, autonomy tools, and data so that â€œevery robot learns from every robot.â€

  • Serveâ€™s sidewalk fleet, which runs on both DoorDash and Uber Eats networks, scaled from 100 to more than 2K robots over the past year.

Why it matters: This deal turns Serve from a niche food-delivery player into one of the first companies running a shared autonomy stack across both public sidewalks and hospital corridors â€” a real-world stress test for â€œphysical AI,â€ the bet that one platform can learn to navigate any human-occupied space and port those lessons everywhere.

QUICK HITS

ðŸ“°Â Everything else in robotics today

1Xâ€™s VP of AI, Eric Jang, who helped scale 1X from a small Norway-based startup to a global humanoid giant, announced on X that he is leaving the company.

Chinese robotics firm UBTechÂ signed a deal to supply its Walker S2 humanoids to Airbus for aviation manufacturing, which sent UBTechâ€™s shares surging.

UBTech says its Walker S2 humanoids are now autonomously performing assembly and material-handling tasks inside a Chinese wind turbine factory.

XPengâ€™s CEO, He Xiaopeng,Â said their automotive-grade ET1 humanoid has rolled off the production line, with the first mass-produced test units focused on reliability.

Hyundaiâ€™s Boston DynamicsÂ hired Milan Kovac, Teslaâ€™s former senior VP and head of the Optimus humanoid program, as a group adviser and outside director.

DEEP RoboticsÂ launched an AI-powered firefighting system that uses coordinated robot dogs and other specialized robots to handle high-risk firefighting missions.

MicrosoftÂ unveiled Rho-alpha, a robotics AI that converts everyday language into robot actions by combining vision and touch for more reliable real-world manipulation.

Boston Dynamics updated its Spot platform and Orbit software to version 5.1 and introduced the Spot Cam 2 sensor head, sharpening its inspection capabilities.

Zhejiang University researchers built FlexiRay, a soft robotic gripper that uses an internal camera and mirror system to â€œseeâ€ around corners.

COMMUNITY

ðŸŽ“ Highlights: News, Guides & Events

  • Read our last AI newsletter: Anthropic writes Claude's Constitution

  • Read our last Tech newsletter: Biotechâ€™s big three (and theyâ€™re wild)

  • Read our last Robotics newsletter: 1X now has a world model

  • Todayâ€™s AI tool guide: Make Claude an expert at anything with Skills repo

  • RSVP to next workshop @ 4PM EST Thursday: AI Foundations Bootcamp pt.3

That's it for today!

Before you go we'd love to know what you thought of today's newsletter to help us improve The Rundown experience for you.

ðŸ¤–ðŸ¤–ðŸ¤–ðŸ¤–ðŸ¤– Nailed it

ðŸ¤–ðŸ¤–ðŸ¤– Average

ðŸ¤– Fail

See you soon,

Rowan, Joey, Zach, Shubham, and Jennifer â€” The Rundownâ€™s editorial team

item.title: AI Frontiers on Hacker News
item.description:
AI Frontiers on Hacker News
January 22, 2026
Your brain on ChatGPT: Accumulation of cognitive debt when using an AI assistant
â€¢ Article: https://www.media.mit.edu/publications/your-brain-on-chatgpt/
â€¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46712678
â€¢ Score: 383
â€¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
â€¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • â€¢ A study compared essay writing across three groups: AI-powered Large Language Models (LLMs), Search Engine users, and Brain-only (no tools). Results showed LLM users had the weakest brain connectivity and lowest cognitive engagement, while Brain-only participants demonstrated the strongest neural activity.
  • â€¢ LLM reliance led to reduced cognitive ownership and long-term underperformance in neural, linguistic, and behavioral metrics. Participants transitioning from LLMs to Brain-only writing struggled with cognitive engagement, raising concerns about AI's educational impact.
  • â€¢ Findings highlight the trade-offs between immediate convenience offered by LLMs and potential cognitive costs, emphasizing the need for further research into AI's role in learning.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Themes and Topics**:
  • â€¢ **Cognitive Impact of AI Usage**: Many commenters discussed how relying on AI, particularly for tasks like coding or essay writing, can lead to cognitive atrophy, reduced engagement, and diminished understanding of the underlying material. However, others noted that AI can be a valuable tool when used correctly, such as for explaining concepts or accelerating productivity.
  • â€¢ **Historical Comparisons**: A recurring theme was comparing AI to past technological advancements (e.g., writing, calculators, GPS). Commenters debated whether these tools fundamentally shifted or diminished human cognitive abilities and whether similar concerns about AI are justified.
  • â€¢ **AI as a Tool vs. Replacement**: Several commenters highlighted the distinction between using AI as an assistive tool versus allowing it to take over tasks entirely. Many advocated for using AI to augment human work rather than replace critical thinking or hands-on learning.
  • â€¢ **Educational and Long-Term Implications**: Concerns were raised about how reliance on AI might affect learning, skill development, and problem-solving over time. Commenters discussed the potential for AI to disrupt traditional education and training pipelines, particularly in fields like programming.
  • â€¢ **Personal Experiences with AI**: Commenters shared anecdotes about their own experiences with AI tools, ranging from increased productivity and overcoming ADHD-related challenges to feeling disengaged or frustrated when relying too heavily on AI.
  • 2. **Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • â€¢ **Agreements**:
  • â€¢ Many agreed that over-reliance on AI can lead to skill atrophy and reduced cognitive engagement.
  • â€¢ There was broad consensus that AI tools are most effective when used as aids for learning or productivity rather than as replacements for human effort.
  • â€¢ Several commenters supported the idea that AI should be used to focus on higher-level tasks while offloading repetitive or tedious work.
  • â€¢ **Disagreements**:
  • â€¢ Some commenters believed that AI is fundamentally different from past tools like calculators or writing because it can take over entire cognitive processes, while others argued that such concerns mirror historical fears about new technologies.
  • â€¢ There was debate about whether the downsides of AI use outweigh its benefits, with some emphasizing the risks of cognitive decline and others highlighting its potential for augmenting human capabilities.
  • â€¢ A few commenters dismissed the study as flawed or unscientific, while others found its findings credible and aligned with their own observations.
  • 3. **Unique Insights and Notable Contributions**:
  • â€¢ Several commenters noted the importance of actively engaging with AI tools (e.g., asking questions, fact-checking) to mitigate cognitive atrophy and enhance learning.
  • â€¢ A comparison was made between managing AI and managing human subordinates, suggesting that principles of good management could inform effective AI use.
  • â€¢ Some highlighted the potential for AI to create a divide between those who rely heavily on it and those who retain traditional problem-solving skills, potentially leading to a "talent crunch" in certain fields.
  • â€¢ A few commenters proposed solutions to mitigate AI's negative effects, such as using it to create personalized learning experiences or imposing limits on its accessibility.
  • 4. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • â€¢ The discussion was mixed, with a balance of cautious optimism and concern. While many commenters acknowledged the productivity and learning benefits of AI, there was significant apprehension about its long-term cognitive and societal impacts. The tone ranged from reflective and analytical to skeptical and critical, with occasional humor and sarcasm.
  • 5. **Key Takeaways**:
  • â€¢ AI tools can enhance productivity and learning but require careful, intentional use to avoid negative cognitive effects.
  • â€¢ Historical parallels suggest that concerns about AI may be part of a broader pattern of initial resistance to new technologies, though AI's unique capabilities raise distinct challenges.
  • â€¢ The long-term implications of AI reliance on education, skill development, and societal structures remain uncertain and warrant further research and consideration.
How AI destroys institutions
â€¢ Article: https://cyberlaw.stanford.edu/publications/how-ai-destroys-institutions/
â€¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46705606
â€¢ Score: 298
â€¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
â€¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • â€¢ Civic institutions like the rule of law, universities, and a free press rely on transparency, cooperation, and accountability to adapt and sustain democratic life, empowering individuals to challenge norms and foster stability.
  • â€¢ Current AI systems undermine these foundational principles by eroding expertise, disrupting decision-making processes, and isolating individuals, making them incompatible with the evolution and legitimacy of civic institutions.
  • â€¢ The essay argues that AIâ€™s design and functionality pose a severe threat to the survival of vital democratic structures, calling for urgent recognition of this existential risk.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Themes and Topics**:
  • â€¢ The role of AI in accelerating societal changes and its impact on institutions like universities, the press, and the rule of law.
  • â€¢ The debate over whether AI is the root cause of institutional decline or merely an accelerant of pre-existing issues.
  • â€¢ Concerns about AI eroding expertise, critical thinking, and interpersonal connections.
  • â€¢ Broader societal factors contributing to the erosion of trust in institutions, such as capitalism, corruption, and social media.
  • â€¢ The potential for AI to democratize access to knowledge and tools, but also the risks of misinformation and accountability gaps.
  • 2. **Key Points of Agreement**:
  • â€¢ Many commenters agree that AI is amplifying existing problems rather than creating them from scratch.
  • â€¢ There is consensus that institutions were already facing challenges, such as declining trust, inefficiency, and corruption, before the rise of AI.
  • â€¢ AIâ€™s ability to enhance productivity and accessibility is acknowledged, but it comes with the caveat of needing careful management.
  • 3. **Key Points of Disagreement**:
  • â€¢ Some commenters argue that AI should be blamed for accelerating institutional decline, likening it to "throwing gas on a fire," while others believe the root causes lie elsewhere, such as in capitalism or systemic failures.
  • â€¢ Diverging views on whether AI is fundamentally destructive or can be harnessed positively to complement institutions.
  • â€¢ Opinions differ on whether institutions like universities and the press are still essential or have become outdated and self-serving.
  • 4. **Unique Insights**:
  • â€¢ Several commenters highlight that institutional fragility predates AI and is tied to broader societal trends, such as the commodification of education and the influence of profit-driven motives.
  • â€¢ A commenter draws parallels between AI and previous technological disruptions, such as the internet and YouTube, which restructured traditional industries without completely destroying them.
  • â€¢ Another perspective emphasizes the potential for AI to exacerbate societal inequalities by empowering those who can use it effectively while disadvantaging others.
  • 5. **Sentiment of the Discussion**:
  • â€¢ The overall sentiment is mixed, with a blend of skepticism, concern, and cautious optimism.
  • â€¢ Many commenters express frustration with existing institutions and their inability to adapt, but there is also apprehension about AIâ€™s potential to destabilize society further.
  • â€¢ Some comments reflect a sense of inevitability about AI-driven changes, while others call for proactive regulation and accountability.
  • 6. **Notable Contributions**:
  • â€¢ The analogy of AI as a "wrecking ball" or "accelerant" was frequently used to describe its impact on fragile systems.
  • â€¢ Commenters debated the role of institutional trust, with some arguing that institutions must earn trust by improving lives, while others believe trust has eroded due to systemic corruption.
  • â€¢ The discussion touched on the dual nature of AI: as a tool for empowerment and democratization, but also as a potential source of harm if misused.
  • 7. **Concluding Observations**:
  • â€¢ The discussion reflects deep concerns about the interplay between AI and societal structures, with no clear consensus on how to address the challenges.
  • â€¢ While some commenters see AI as a tool for progress, others view it as a threat to the foundational principles of democratic life.
  • â€¢ The debate underscores the need for thoughtful regulation, transparency, and public accountability in the deployment of AI technologies.
eBay explicitly bans AI "buy for me" agents in user agreement update
â€¢ Article: https://www.valueaddedresource.net/ebay-bans-ai-agents-updates-arbitration-user-agreement-feb-2026/
â€¢ HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46711574
â€¢ Score: 209
â€¢ Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
â€¢ AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • â€¢ eBay explicitly prohibits AI-driven "buy for me" agents and large language model (LLM) bots from interacting with its platform without prior permission, aiming to prevent unauthorized automated transactions and data scraping.
  • â€¢ Arbitration updates include clarified class action waivers, an opt-out process, and a revised physical address for dispute notices, enhancing transparency in dispute resolution.
  • â€¢ The move aligns with broader industry concerns, potentially responding to Amazon's controversial AI-powered commerce experiments, highlighting growing scrutiny around AI's role in e-commerce.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Theme**: The discussion centers on eBay's ban on AI-powered "buy-for-me" bots, with participants debating the rationale, implications, and fairness of the decision.
  • 2. **Key Points of Discussion**:
  • â€¢ **eBay's Motivation**:
  • â€¢ Several commenters argue that the ban is primarily about protecting eBay's business model, particularly its reliance on impulse buying, ad revenue, and user engagement ("wandering attention").
  • â€¢ Others suggest the ban is aimed at avoiding potential liabilities, such as AI errors leading to incorrect purchases, returns, or scams.
  • â€¢ Some see it as a move to prevent AI from commoditizing eBay into a backend database, reducing its role in the user experience.
  • â€¢ **Fairness and Double Standards**:
  • â€¢ Many express frustration that eBay allows sniping bots (which bid at the last moment in auctions) but bans "buy-for-me" bots, viewing this as inconsistent.
  • â€¢ Some commenters note that sniping bots benefit eBay by keeping users engaged on the platform, whereas "buy-for-me" bots bypass user interaction and reduce ad exposure.
  • â€¢ **User Experience and AI Utility**:
  • â€¢ Several commenters highlight the potential usefulness of AI agents for tasks like monitoring listings, identifying deals, and automating purchases, particularly for niche or time-sensitive needs.
  • â€¢ Concerns are raised about the challenges of teaching AI to accurately interpret user preferences and avoid errors.
  • â€¢ Some suggest that eBay's poor user experience, including excessive notifications and spam, pushes users toward automating their interactions via AI.
  • â€¢ **Scalability and Abuse**:
  • â€¢ Participants discuss the potential for AI-driven automation to be abused at scale, such as by drop shippers or arbitrageurs who scrape listings and relist them for profit, creating additional load on platforms.
  • â€¢ Commenters also note that such automation could lead to increased returns, cancellations, and fraud, further straining eBay's infrastructure.
  • â€¢ **Enforcement Challenges**:
  • â€¢ Many are skeptical about eBay's ability to enforce the ban, given the sophistication of bots and the difficulty of distinguishing them from human users.
  • â€¢ Others argue that the ban is more about creating a policy framework to address issues as they arise rather than immediate, proactive enforcement.
  • 3. **Unique Insights**:
  • â€¢ Some commenters suggest that eBay could monetize AI interactions by licensing API access or offering official AI tools, similar to how other companies are adapting to AI's impact.
  • â€¢ There is a broader reflection on how AI could disrupt marketplaces by leveling the playing field against existing automation (e.g., sniping bots, scalpers).
  • 4. **Sentiment**:
  • â€¢ The overall sentiment is mixed, with significant skepticism toward eBay's motives and policies. While some acknowledge the potential risks of AI automation, many view the ban as self-serving and indicative of broader issues with eBay's business practices and user experience.
  • 5. **Notable Contributions**:
  • â€¢ A few commenters highlight practical use cases for AI in e-commerce, such as assisting blind users or automating complex purchase decisions.
  • â€¢ Others share personal experiences with eBay, illustrating frustrations with fees, fraud, and the platform's declining usability.
  • 6. **Broader Implications**:
  • â€¢ The discussion reflects a larger tension between the benefits of AI-driven automation for users and the challenges it poses for businesses reliant on traditional engagement models.
  • â€¢ Commenters note parallels with other industries adapting to AI, suggesting that eBay's move is part of a broader trend of companies seeking to protect their revenue streams in the face of technological disruption.
Letting Claude play text adventures

Article Summary:

  • â€¢ An AI hackathon participant experimented with combining cognitive architecture principles, like those from Soar and ACT-R, with large language models (LLMs) to improve their performance in long-horizon tasks, using text adventure games as a testing ground.
  • â€¢ The project highlighted challenges such as token limitations and memory management in LLMs, leading to the development of experimental harnesses, including semantic memory and task-specific tools, to enhance efficiency and gameplay navigation.
  • â€¢ Future plans include implementing domain-specific memories, automatic and manual geography mapping, and episodic memory to refine LLMs' ability to handle complex, structured environments more effectively.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topic**: The discussion revolves around using large language models (LLMs), particularly Claude, to play text adventure games, with a focus on memory management, reasoning capabilities, and experimental frameworks.
  • 2. **Themes**:
  • â€¢ **Training Data and Performance**: Several commenters speculate on whether Claude's training data includes walkthroughs or transcripts of games like Anchorhead. Opinions vary on whether this would impact its ability to solve puzzles effectively.
  • â€¢ **Memory and Context Management**: There is significant discussion on how LLMs handle memory, with suggestions for structured memory tools, periodic summaries, and context compaction to improve performance in long-running sessions.
  • â€¢ **Symbolic AI and Hybrid Approaches**: Some commenters debate the relevance of symbolic AI in modern systems, suggesting it could serve as scaffolding for LLMs to handle causality and constraints better.
  • â€¢ **Applications and Experiments**: Commenters share their experiments, such as using Claude to play MUDs, Z-Machine games, and Dwarf Fortress clones, highlighting its potential for testing interactive fiction and software development.
  • â€¢ **Challenges with LLMs**: Observations include inefficiencies in maze-solving, high token costs for long sessions, and the inability of LLMs to manage their own memory optimally.
  • 3. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • â€¢ There is general agreement that LLMs struggle with memory management and could benefit from external tools or structured frameworks.
  • â€¢ Some commenters are skeptical about the performance of LLMs in solving puzzles or playing games, especially if the games are well-known and potentially included in training data.
  • â€¢ Others highlight promising use cases for LLMs, such as testing game development or enhancing text adventure experiences.
  • 4. **Sentiment**:
  • â€¢ The sentiment is mixed. Many commenters express enthusiasm for the potential of LLMs in gaming and testing applications, while others are critical of their current limitations, such as inefficiencies and lack of contextual awareness.
  • 5. **Unique Insights**:
  • â€¢ Several commenters propose innovative approaches to improve LLM performance, such as combining structured memory tools with symbolic AI, externalizing geometry in mazes, and using file-based memory types to mimic human-like recall.
  • â€¢ The idea of using LLMs for CI/CD testing in interactive fiction development is highlighted as a novel application.
  • â€¢ The concept of treating memory as structured game objects with explicit states and affordances is proposed as a way to enhance reasoning and coherence.
  • 6. **Overall Summary**:
  • â€¢ The discussion showcases both the potential and limitations of LLMs in playing text adventure games. While there is excitement about experimental frameworks and applications, commenters emphasize the need for better memory management and structured approaches to improve reasoning and gameplay capabilities. Hybrid approaches combining symbolic AI and LLMs are suggested as a promising direction for addressing current challenges.
Comic-Con Bans AI Art After Artist Pushback

Article Summary:

  • â€¢ San Diego Comic-Con reversed its AI-friendly policy for its art show after an artist-led protest, now banning all AI-generated content to protect the integrity of creative work.
  • â€¢ Artists like Karla Ortiz highlighted how generative AI undermines livelihoods by replacing traditional creative processes, with examples from Marvel and Coca-Cola showcasing the growing industry reliance on AI.
  • â€¢ Despite the policy change, concerns persist as AI-generated art continues to appear at conventions, raising ethical debates about its exploitation of original artworks without credit or compensation.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Themes and Topics**:
  • â€¢ The ethics and legitimacy of AI-generated art, particularly in creative spaces like conventions.
  • â€¢ The evolving definition of art and the boundaries between traditional, digital, and AI-assisted creation.
  • â€¢ Concerns about authenticity, craftsmanship, and the impact of AI on artistic livelihoods.
  • â€¢ The role of tools and technology in the creative process, including comparisons to past innovations like Photoshop and photography.
  • 2. **Key Points of Discussion**:
  • â€¢ Many commenters argue that AI-generated art lacks the moral and creative authenticity valued by traditional artists, especially when training data involves unconsented use of existing works.
  • â€¢ There is disagreement over whether AI tools are simply another medium for creativity or if they undermine the artistic process by removing human skill and effort.
  • â€¢ Some contributors highlight historical parallels, such as debates around digital art and the use of assistants in traditional art, suggesting that resistance to new technologies is not new.
  • â€¢ Others propose a spectrum of AI involvement in art, ranging from minor assistance to fully AI-generated works, with the degree of human engagement influencing perceptions of value and authenticity.
  • â€¢ Concerns about false accusations of AI use and the potential for AI-generated content to dominate spaces like conventions were also raised.
  • 3. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • â€¢ There is broad agreement that generative AI raises ethical concerns, particularly around copyright and training data. However, views differ on whether AI art can or should be considered "real art.
  • â€¢ Some commenters believe AI tools could be valuable for enhancing creativity or automating repetitive tasks, while others feel they fundamentally devalue artistic work.
  • â€¢ Disagreement exists over whether AI art will eventually be accepted as part of the artistic landscape, with some predicting it will follow the trajectory of past technological shifts and others expressing skepticism about its long-term viability in creative fields.
  • 4. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • â€¢ The sentiment is mixed but leans toward skepticism and concern about the implications of AI art on creativity, ethics, and artistic livelihoods. While some commenters are optimistic about AI's potential as a tool, many express fears about its impact on authenticity and the art community.
  • 5. **Unique Insights and Contributions**:
  • â€¢ Comparisons to Andy Warhol's factory and historical shifts in art (e.g., photography) suggest that art has always balanced ideas and skill, and AI might represent another stage in this evolution.
  • â€¢ The notion of AI art as a form of "false scarcity" or simulacrum highlights deeper philosophical concerns about the nature of creativity and substance in art.
  • â€¢ Practical observations, such as AI scrapers impacting artists' websites and conventions banning AI art, underscore real-world tensions between traditional and AI-assisted art.
  • 6. **Conclusion**:
  • â€¢ The discussion reflects an ongoing debate about the place of AI in the creative world, with strong opinions on both sides. While some see AI as a tool that can complement human creativity, others worry it undermines the essence of art and the livelihoods of artists. The conversation highlights ethical, philosophical, and practical challenges that will likely continue as AI technologies evolve.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Themes and Topics**:
  • â€¢ The productivity gains from using large language models (LLMs) like ChatGPT are debated, with some users finding them convenient but not revolutionary, while others highlight issues like hallucinations and inaccuracies.
  • â€¢ Concerns about the hype surrounding AI and its practical utility are prevalent. Many commenters question whether AI has found genuinely transformative applications or if it's largely a bubble driven by investor pressure.
  • â€¢ Energy consumption, hardware costs, and resource usage for AI systems are criticized, with some commenters pointing out the environmental and economic impacts of the AI industry's growth.
  • â€¢ Specific use cases for AI are discussed, including customer service, software development, healthcare, and personal finance. While some see incremental benefits, others argue these applications are limited or flawed.
  • â€¢ Skepticism about the broader societal and economic implications of AI, including its potential to replace jobs and the erosion of trust due to hype and hallucinated outputs.
  • 2. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • â€¢ There is general agreement that AI tools like ChatGPT are useful for specific tasks, such as coding assistance or summarizing information. However, opinions differ on whether these tools are truly revolutionary or just incremental improvements.
  • â€¢ Many commenters express frustration with the hallucination problem in LLMs, which can lead to wasted time and unreliable outputs. Some argue this undermines the claimed productivity gains.
  • â€¢ A divide exists between those who see AI as a transformative technology with vast potential and those who view it as overhyped and struggling to justify its costs.
  • â€¢ The sentiment around AI in healthcare is mixed, with some noting its potential for assisting doctors and automating tasks, while others emphasize the challenges of data quality, legal compliance, and the limitations of generative AI in this field.
  • 3. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • â€¢ The discussion leans toward skepticism, with many commenters questioning the current state of AI, its practical utility, and the motivations behind its development and promotion.
  • â€¢ There is also a sense of frustration with the hype cycle and the perception that AI is being pushed as a solution without clearly defined problems to solve.
  • â€¢ Some optimism is present, particularly among users who have found specific, niche applications of AI to be genuinely helpful.
  • 4. **Unique Insights and Contributions**:

  • â€¢ Concerns are raised about the long-term sustainability of AI advancements, with one commenter predicting that free or cheap AI will eventually become ad-driven and less capable unless users pay a premium for quality.
  • 5. **Broader Observations**:
  • â€¢ Several commenters note the potential societal harm caused by the AI hype bubble, including resource consumption, eroded trust, and the promotion of unsafe or ineffective technologies.
  • â€¢ The discussion reflects a growing awareness of the limitations of generative AI and the need for more meaningful, impactful applications to justify the immense investment in the field.

State of Markets

Snapshots from the public and private markets on AI, company-building, and more

David George
Jan 22
∙
Guest post
 
READ IN APP
 

We’re pleased to share our inaugural “State of Markets” slide deck. We share what we’re seeing in the private and public markets, what the state of AI looks like to us, and why today’s winners are just built different.

You can read the deck here (it takes a second to load, there’s a lot in there):

State of Markets

Here’s a sample of what’s in there:

Unicorns are real…

It’s a power law business; always has been. In 2025, Revenue growth exploded upwards for the top quartile and top decile companies, far more than for everybody else.

And they run in herds.

As private unicorns broke through the $5T mark in aggregate, it’s clear who’s driving the trend: the biggest names.

Subscribe for more from a16z every weekday:

Subscribed

Meanwhile, in the public markets, a similar story is playing out:

Higher the earnings, higher the multiple

Winners keep winning, whether we’re talking sectors or individual winners. This isn’t a “1x EV TAM” kind of market: the biggest multiples are getting assigned to the big earnings day winners.

Tech is its own supercycle

Zooming out, those winners tend to be tech companies, and those tech companies have pulled far away from everybody else. Tech isn’t just a subset of companies; it’s increasingly “the great companies”, full stop.

But… is it a bubble?

At a16z Runtime late last year, we heard from Google that 7-8 year old TPUs are still running at 100% utilization…

And Jevons’ Paradox is certainly real this time around. The cheaper the tokens get, the more they’re used - especially when indirectly monetized.

All that’s to say, at the end of the day, it’s got to pay back. Here’s what that’ll take:

(Because a billion dollars isn’t cool. You know what’s cool? A trillion dollars.)

You can view the whole deck here:

State of Markets

Thanks for reading! If you don’t already subscribe, get more from a16z every weekday by clicking right here:

item.title: AI Agenda: Why Some Researchers at OpenAI, Thinking Machines and Amazon Want to Change How LLMs Are Trained
item.description:
AI Agenda
It seems like every AI researcher these days has lots of ideas around how to combat major shortcomings in the field, such as the â€œsplit-brain problemâ€ (in which a model can incorrectly answer a question just because of the way the question is phrased), by developing new models that do â€œcontinual learning,â€ for instance.͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­͏ ‌     ­
Jan 22, 2026

AI Agenda
By Stephanie Palazzolo
Supported by

Thank you for reading the AI Agenda Newsletter! Iâ€™d love your feedback, ideas and tips: stephanie@theinformation.com.

If you think someone else might enjoy this newsletter, please pass it forward or they can sign upÂ here.

Hello!

It seems like every AI researcher these days has lots of ideas around how to combat major shortcomings in the field, such as the â€œsplit-brain problemâ€ (in which a model can incorrectly answer a question just because of the way the question is phrased), by developing new models that do â€œcontinual learning,â€ for instance.

AI researchers also tell me theyâ€™re interested in revamping the model training process. Some researchers, including Amazonâ€™s David Luan, say the current order of steps ofÂ pretraining (giving it a broad, general knowledge of the world) before posttraining (honing its knowledge in specific domains) donâ€™t make much sense.Â 

This order of steps has become the norm in AI because, in some ways, it makes intuitive sense: humans similarly require a general base of knowledge you learn during childhood before learning more specific skills later on in life.

But Luan says that if you know a model will be used for coding or helping with customer refunds, why spend so much effort teaching the model about completely irrelevant topics, like poetry or horticulture?Â 

His argument is that it makes more sense to use the pretraining process to expose the model to more curated data related to the task it is destined to handle. The idea is to prepare the model for its eventual purpose.Â 

Researchers from a variety of other major developers, including OpenAI and Thinking Machines Lab, agree. Some even think that AI developers should do away with separate teams for the different stages of model training and just consolidate everyone into a single training team.

If this comes to fruition, however, it will have important implications for the way AI is developed.

Researchers will have to decide what curated data they want to include earlier in the training process, which can affect what the model is and isnâ€™t good at. (For instance, a decision to include more math and code and less prose data during early training could make the model worse at creative writing or speaking warmly to users.)Â 

This most likely would lead to a future of many specialized models trained on different datasets, rather than whatâ€™s most common today: researchers using the same pretrained model but making tweaks during posttraining to get it to perform better at different tasks.

Already, weâ€™re seeing examples of places where such an approach could be helpful. As Sri, Amir and I wrote about here, one problem OpenAI is facing is that what consumers want out of ChatGPTâ€”help with relatively simple questions and a friend to talk toâ€”doesnâ€™t align with the cutting-edge research the company is doing in areas like reasoning models to get to superintelligence, or AI that can help us colonize Mars or find new cures for diseases.

OpenAI is already acknowledging this divide by using a router to direct ChatGPT queries to be handled by different models depending on how complicated they are, and by creating specialized models like GPT-5-Codex (though all of the models are based on the same pretrained model).Â 

Doubling down on this by training completely different models for ChatGPT, scientific research or coding, for instance, would require the company to completely revamp its research team.

Microsoft Backs Photonics Startup

Investor enthusiasm has been mounting for startups that use light instead of electrons in hardware for data centersâ€”specifically to use light to ferry data among chips in data centers.Â 

Neurophos is taking a different tack. The six-year-old startup designs chips that use light to perform the mathematical operations involved in running AI models. And it just raised $110 million in a Series A funding round led by Gates Frontier, Bill Gatesâ€™ venture firm, according to Patrick Bowen, co-founder and CEO of Neurophos.

M12, Microsoftâ€™s venture firm, also participated in the round. Backing from Microsoft, one of the biggest cloud providers, is a sign of confidence in the technology.

â€œModern AI inference demands monumental amounts of power and compute,â€ said Marc Tremblay, corporate vice president and technical fellow of core AI infrastructure at Microsoft in a statement. â€œWe need a breakthrough in compute on par with the leaps weâ€˜ve seen in AI models themselves, which is what Neurophosâ€™ technology and high-talent density team is developing.â€

The appeal of using light is that it could be much more energy-efficient than electrons for running AI models. The chip the startup expects to deliver in 2028 will be 50 times as fast and 50 times as efficient as an Nvidia Blackwell, said Bowen.Â 

The funding round also included participation from Carbon Direct Capital, Aramco Ventures, Bosch Ventures, Tectonic Ventures and Space Capital, DNX Ventures, Geometry, MetaVC Partners, Morgan Creek Capital, Silicon Catalyst Ventures, Mana Ventures and Gaingel.â€”Rocket Drew

Hereâ€™s what else is going onâ€¦

Claude Gets a Revamped Constitution

Anthropic yesterday released its new â€œconstitutionâ€ for Claude, essentially, a document that provides guidelines for how the model should act and respond in more â€œgray areaâ€ situations. This is the first publicly-released update the company has made to its Claude constitution since it first released the document in 2023.

Compared to the original constitution, the updated version is less prescriptive and treats the model more like an intelligent entity with its own sense of good judgment by, for instance, explaining the reasoning behind the rules it provides rather than just listing them outright. Interestingly, the document also leaves room for the possibility that Claude has some sort of â€œconsciousnessâ€ or â€œmoral status,â€ a change from the original document.

Overheard

OpenAI CFO Sarah Friar said the companyâ€™s custom inference chip is being â€œtaped outâ€â€”the final step before manufacturingâ€”and touted the progress of its more than $500 billion Stargate infrastructure project in a panel at the World Economic Forum Wednesday.

On Stargate, which was announced one year ago, she said that the project is â€œwell over halfway built outâ€ and OpenAI is already training models on servers at Oracleâ€™s Stargate campus. â€œItâ€™s gone better than we all dreamed,â€ she said.

Deals and Debuts

See The Informationâ€™s Generative AI Database for an exclusive list of private companies and their investors.

Lightning AI, which offers software for customizing AI models, and data center provider Voltage Park merged into a single company, still called Lightning AI, that is valued at over $2.5 billion.

Recommendation app Yelp on Wednesday said it agreed to acquire AI agent startup Hatch for $300 million, or roughly 12 times the startupâ€™s annual recurring revenue.

Upscale AI, which provides networking equipment for AI data centers, raised $200 million in a Series A funding round led by Tiger Global, Premji Invest and Xora Innovation.

Zanskar, which uses AI to search for geothermal energy, raised $115 million in a Series C funding round led by Spring Lane Capital.

AheadComputing, which designs CPU chips for AI data centers, raised $30 million in a seed extension funding round led by Eclipse, Toyota Ventures and Cambium.

Google DeepMind is hiring the CEO and several top engineers from Hume AI, a startup developing voice AI models, as part of a licensing agreement. The terms of the deal werenâ€™t disclosed.

Apple is developing an AI-powered wearable pin that could be released as early as 2027, The Information reported. Apple plans to bring more conversational capabilities to Siri, turning it more into a chatbot like ChatGPT, Bloomberg reported. Bloomberg also reported that Apple is in talks with Google about using the companyâ€™s cloud infrastructure, including its AI chips, tensor processing units, to launch the updated Siri.

Amazon-owned primary care chain One Medical said it is launching an AI health assistant.

Shopify has told merchants that use its commerce software that it will open up sales through AI chatbots like ChatGPT later this month, according to its site and communications with sellers.

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang is preparing for a trip to China later this month as the company works to regain its footing in this strategically important market, Bloomberg reported, citing a person with knowledge of the plans.

Meta CTO Andrew Bosworth said at a press conference that Meta Superintelligence Labs delivered its first AI models internally this month, Reuters reported.

The White House Council of Economic Advisers released a report on â€œArtificial Intelligence and the Great Divergence,â€ writing that â€œthe advent of generative artificial intelligence based around large language models (LLMs) will initiate a new wave of profound economic transformation in the United States, promising significant boosts to productivity and growth.â€

YouTube will work on managing AI â€œslopâ€ videos on the site this year, while adding AI tools to generate short-form videos using your own likeness, CEO Neal Mohan wrote in his annual letter.

Microsoft announced Rho-alpha, a new AI model for powering robots, based on its Phi language models.

Now your people can AI like they were meant to AI.

Introducing the AI Experience by ServiceNow. Most AI is stuck in silos. Trapped in apps. Disconnected from how people actually work. The AI Experience by ServiceNowÂ® works the way people do. It brings text, voice, images, and agents into a single, seamless interface where AI is the new UI. Learn more

Headlines & Launches

Claude's new constitution (12 minute read)

Anthropic has published a new constitution for Claude. The document is a detailed description of Anthropic's vision for Claude's values and behavior that explains the context in which Claude operates and the kind of entity the company would like Claude to be. The constitution is a crucial part of the model training process, and its content directly shapes Claude's behavior. This post describes what's included in the new constitution and some of the considerations that informed Anthropic's approach.
OpenAI's Altman Meets Mideast Investors for $50 Billion Round (2 minute read)

OpenAI's CEO, Sam Altman, has been meeting with investors in the Middle East to line up funding for a new investment round that could total at least $50 billion. He recently visited the region, where he spoke with some of the leading state-backed funds in Abu Dhabi. The talks are early, and the amount could change. OpenAI has also recently held talks with Amazon to raise at least $10 billion.
Meta's new AI team delivered first key models internally this month, CTO says (3 minute read)

Meta's new artificial intelligence lab has delivered its first high-profile models internally. The company's CTO, Andrew Bosworth, says the models show a lot of promise. There is still a tremendous amount of work required in the post-training phase before the models can be delivered in a way that's usable internally and by consumers. Meta is starting to see favorable returns from its big gambits in 2025. The next two years will be important for bringing consumer products to market.
ðŸ§ 

Deep Dives & Analysis

Pass@k is Mostly Bunk (3 minute read)

Pass@k is the probability that at least one of k different attempts will succeed. It is one of the most common metrics used for agents. The problem with the metric is that it's exponentially forgiving, and humans interacting with agents aren't nearly that forgiving. Pass@k should be a metric that's rarely used, and carefully justified every time it is used.
GLM4-MoE Inference with SGLang (11 minute read)

Novita AI introduced performance optimizations for GLM4-MoE models using SGLang, achieving faster Time-to-First-Token and better token generation speed under agentic coding workloads.
Claude Codes #3 (24 minute read)

This post contains a curated list of news, tutorials, tips, and articles on Claude Code. It covers recent upgrades, tools that complement Claude Code, and more. The post provides advice on how to skill up with Claude Code as well as predictions on where the technology is headed.

In this report, you'll see how teams are managing risks and improving orchestration to deliver reliable AI agents. Get the report
Devin Review: AI to Stop Slop (4 minute read)

Devin Review is a code review tool that uses AI and UX to scale human understanding of complex code diffs. It is currently free and works on any public or private GitHub PR. The tool helps in every step of the PR process. It allows developers to chat about changes without leaving the review.
MCP is Not the Problem, It's your Server: Best Practices for Building MCP Servers (9 minute read)

When the Model Context Protocol (MCP) exploded a year ago, everyone rushed to build MCP servers. A year later, most MCP servers disappoint. While developers blame the protocol, enterprise adoption tells a different story. Companies are deploying MCP servers, and integrations are live. This post breaks down why MCP servers fail, best practices for building ones that work, and how Skills and MCP complement each other.
Multiplex Thinking for Reasoning Tasks (GitHub Repo)

This implementation introduces token-wise branch-and-merge reasoning to enable more expressive multi-path computation while keeping token representations compact.

Apple plans to make Siri an AI chatbot (2 minute read)

Apple plans to transform Siri into a chatbot, similar to ChatGPT, with the expected launch integrated into iOS 27. The revamped Siri, codenamed "Campos," will support both voice and text inputs, marking a strategic shift due to competitive pressure. Apple has chosen Google's Gemini as its AI partner after evaluating options like OpenAI and Anthropic.
Notion working on custom MCPs, Workers, and Computer Use (2 minute read)

Notion is expanding its Custom Agent platform to include Slack integration and plans for Calendar and Mail connectors for automation. Integrations with third-party services like Cursor, Linear, and Ramp are in development, enhancing project management and finance tasks. New sections like Feed, Library, and Workers will enable developers to create custom integrations, while AI features like an AI co-editor enhance productivity.

AgentOS provides a production-ready runtime for multi-agent AI systems, solving the infrastructure challenges that prevent most projects from shipping.

Apple's strategy focuses on its durable ecosystem, prioritizing hardware sales over AI innovations, despite the industry's AI investment focus.
Claude's new constitution (1 minute read)

Two of the fifteen external contributors who helped review Claude's new constitution are Catholic members of the clergy.

Aliisa Rosenthal, OpenAI's former sales leader, emphasizes context engineering as a key advantage, particularly in enterprise applications, and advocates for developing lighter, cost-effective models.

item.title: Exclusive: How Appleâ€™s Craig Federighi Went From AI Skeptic to Believer
item.description:
With Google Deal, Appleâ€™s Craig Federighi Plots a Cautious Course in AI
Last fall, Appleâ€™s software chief, Craig Federighi, delivered a warm message to a meeting of the companyâ€™s combined software and AI groups. Federighi said he was excited about deeper collaboration between his software team and Appleâ€™s AI group. But then came Federighiâ€™s criticism. He added that he liked moving fast and feeling the â€œwind at his back,â€ but in recent years he had felt Apple hadnâ€™t been moving as quickly as he would have liked in AI. Although he wasnâ€™t explicit, some members of Appleâ€™s foundation models teamâ€”which builds the underlying software that power the companyâ€™s AI featuresâ€”took his comment as a dig at their group.
Jan 22, 2026

Exclusive

With Google Deal, Appleâ€™s Craig Federighi Plots a Cautious Course in AI

By Aaron Tilley and Wayne Ma

Last fall, Appleâ€™s software chief, Craig Federighi, delivered a warm message to a meeting of the companyâ€™s combined software and AI groups. Federighi said he was excited about deeper collaboration between his software team and Appleâ€™s AI group.

But then came Federighiâ€™s criticism. He added that he liked moving fast and feeling the â€œwind at his back,â€ but in recent years he had felt Apple hadnâ€™t been moving as quickly as he would have liked in AI. Although he wasnâ€™t explicit, some members of Appleâ€™s foundation models team—which builds the underlying software that power the companyâ€™s AI features—took his comment as a dig at their group.

Read the full article

The Takeaway

  • Apple software chief Craig Federighi now leads AI organization and is known for his frugality.
  • The appointment and Apple’s decision to partner with Google reflects the company’s cautious approach to AI.
  • Future Apple devices, such as a wearable AI pin, depend on Federighi delivering Siri upgrades.

item.title: The Electric: Trump Moves to Accelerate Seabed Mining of Critical Metals
item.description:
The Electric
Startup Western mining companies got key U.S. support Wednesday in their yearslong effort to extract copper, cobalt and other key metals from the deep Pacific seabed, a move intended to accelerate non-Chinese supplies for tech and defense companies.
Jan 22, 2026

The Electric
By Steve LeVine

Startup Western mining companies got key U.S. support Wednesday in their yearslong effort to extract copper, cobalt and other key metals from the deep Pacific seabed, a move intended to accelerate non-Chinese supplies for tech and defense companies.

In a notice, President Donald Trumpâ€™s administration significantly shortened the permitting process to mine the metals contained in mineral-rich, potato-size nodules scattered by the millions on the Pacific Ocean seabed.

The move could shrink the time it takes to start a mining operation to months from years previously, said Gerard Barron, CEO of The Metals Co. The Canada-based company is a leading explorer in the Clarion-Clipperton Zone, located in the middle of the Pacific Ocean 500 miles southeast of Hawaii, and one of the richest sites for these nodules.

Barron told me TMC would file a revised permit application in line with the new rules on Thursday. After building necessary mining equipment and processing plants, TMC expects to begin mining the nodules before the end of next year. The companyâ€™s share price rose 13% Wednesday on the news.

Wednesdayâ€™s move by the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration aligned with Trumpâ€™s scorn for international agenciesâ€”in this case, the International Seabed Authority, a U.N. body that has been drafting rules for such operations for 11 years. It follows an April executive order by Trump calling for faster seabed mining.

Geopolitics drove Trumpâ€™s order. Since his return to power a year ago, the U.S. and China have engaged in a repeated tit-for-tat fight over exports of critical products. The U.S. has restricted the supply of high-end chips to China, while China has blocked the export of rare earth minerals, graphite and battery components.

China controls about 80% of the worldâ€™s production of cobalt and nickel, used in the defense industry and electric vehicles, and 90% of manganese production. Collectively, however, the nodules in the Clarion-Clipperton Zone, three miles below the surface of the Pacific, contain almost twice as much nickel as all known deposits on land, according to the U.S. Geological Survey, as well as 20% more manganese and more than three times as much cobalt. They also contain significant copper.

TMC is among an international group of startups including ones from Russia, China and Europe that have hounded the International Seabed Authority to issue permits allowing them to vacuum up these nodules. But while the authority has issued dozens of exploration permits, it has issued no actual mining licenses.

Mining startups including TMC have accused the Seabed Authority of deliberately slowing down the licensing process. In prepared remarks Barron is to deliver to a House committee on Thursday, he called the Seabed Authority â€œgridlocked.â€Â 

In April, the Trump administration said it would ignore the Seabed Authority entirely and issue licenses itself. On Wednesday, NOAA moved to expedite the process further, eliminating a requirement that mining startups first obtain an exploration license from the agency, then apply to it for a commercial metals recovery permit. Now startups can apply for both the license and the permit simultaneously.

Oliver Gunasekara, CEO of Impossible Metals, which is seeking to extract nodules in the Clarion-Clipperton Zone as well as offshore of American Samoa, said the U.S. moves appear to be getting the Seabed Authority to move faster.

â€œThe executive order and the fact that The Metals Co. is going direct has put a lot of pressure on the ISA because it now needs to decide if itâ€™s going to be relevant or not,â€ he said.

Edward Boling, a partner at law firm Perkins Coie who worked on sea law in both Republican and Democratic administrations, said the Trump administrationâ€™s moves could backfire if future administrations favor stricter international law, undermining any NOAA permits awarded now.

â€œOur economy is not an island,â€ Boling said. â€œItâ€™s part of the international marketplace. Frankly, I would expect that any developer is going to want to ensure long-term security.â€

Environmental groups have long fought seabed mining, arguing that risks to largely unknown marine ecosystems require tight rules around mining. They are likely to continue their pressure on regulators.

Gunasekara, who is currently raising a $30 million Series A round, said he is sticking with the Seabed Authorityâ€™s process. â€œItâ€™s more legitimate,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s not to say that we donâ€™t think NOAA is a viable approach. But we think that from a longer-term perspective, itâ€™s a safer route to go.â€

Barron, in his prepared remarks, appeared to acknowledge that the durability of the Trump administrationâ€™s decisions was an issue. He urged Congress to write NOAAâ€™s new rules into U.S. law, making it harder for future administrations to change the policy. â€œCapital-intensive offshore industries require confidence that permits will endure over time,â€ he said.
